choices.text: They are made up of bacteria and virus
They can be cultured in cell-free media

questions.text: Which of the following statements about prions is true? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. They are infectious proteins

 

Explanation:


Prions are infectious proteins without any nucleic acid. These proteinaceous infectious particles are responsible for transmissible spongiform encephalopathies. Unlike conventional pathogens, prions consist solely of abnormally folded proteins that can induce normal proteins to also misfold, creating a self-propagating infectious agent without genetic material.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. They are made up of bacteria and virus - This is incorrect. Prions are not composed of bacteria or viruses. They are misfolded proteins with no cellular or viral components. Bacteria are complete prokaryotic cells with cell walls and genetic material, while viruses contain nucleic acid (DNA or RNA) surrounded by a protein coat. Prions lack both cellular structures and nucleic acids.

 

Option C. They have rich nuclear material - This is incorrect. Prions completely lack nucleic acids (DNA or RNA), which distinguishes them from all other infectious agents. They are purely protein in nature with no genetic material whatsoever.

 

Option D. They can be cultured in cell-free media - This is incorrect. Prions cannot be cultivated on cell-free media because they lack the metabolic machinery for self-replication. Unlike bacteria which can grow on nutrient media, prions require host cellular machinery to propagate. They replicate by converting normal proteins to the pathogenic form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prions represent a unique class of infectious agents consisting solely of misfolded proteins without nucleic acids, challenging the central dogma that transmission of biological information requires DNA or RNA.

questions.text: Which of the following jugular venous pressure (JVP) waves corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) c wave

 

The jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform consists of multiple waves that correspond to different phases of the cardiac cycle.

 

The "c" wave corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction, causing a brief increase in pressure in the right atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The "a" wave corresponds to the atrial contraction, which occurs during the late ventricular filling phase of the cardiac cycle. This is the period before the closure of the mitral/ tricuspid valve. The "a" wave is caused by the contraction of the atrium, leading to a brief increase in right atrial pressure.

 

Option C. The "x" descent corresponds to the returning of the tricuspid valve to its normal position during ventricular contraction (i.e. ejection) and atrial relaxation.

 

Option D. The "y" descent corresponds to the rapid emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle during ventricular diastole.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "c" wave of the jugular venous pressure waveform corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle, reflecting the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium as the right ventricle begins to contract.

choices.text: Cold water induces nystagmus to same side
Directional preponderance occurs towards the side of Central lesion

questions.text: All of the following are true about Fitzgerald-Hallpike test, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cold water induces nystagmus to same side

 

Explanation:

 

The Fitzgerald-Hallpike test (bithermal caloric test) uses water at temperatures above and below body temperature to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canal and induce nystagmus. Cold water irrigation induces nystagmus to the opposite side, not the same side. This follows the mnemonic "COWS" (Cold-Opposite, Warm-Same), which indicates that cold water induces nystagmus to the opposite side while warm water induces nystagmus to the same side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bithermal Caloric Test: This is a correct statement. Fitzgerald-Hallpike test is indeed also known as the bithermal caloric test. It uses water at 30°C (cold) and 44°C (warm) to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canals.

 

Option C. Directional preponderance occurs towards the side of Central lesion: This is a correct statement. Directional preponderance (where nystagmus is stronger in one direction than the other) typically occurs toward the side of a central lesion, and away from the side in a peripheral lesion.

 

Option D. All are true: This option is incorrect because statement B is false. Cold water causes nystagmus to the opposite side, not the same side.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In the Fitzgerald-Hallpike caloric test, cold water irrigation causes nystagmus to the opposite side, following the mnemonic "COWS" (Cold-Opposite, Warm-Same), which is a fundamental principle in vestibular testing and helps differentiate various vestibular disorders.

choices.text: 20.8 hours
6.9 hours
13.8 hours

questions.text: The elimination rate constant of a drug is 0.05 hr. What is its half-life? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 13.8 hours

 

  • Half-life is the time in which the plasma concentration of the drug becomes half.
  • The elimination rate constant of a drug reflects the fraction of drug that is removed from the body compartment per unit time.
  • The elimination rate constant = k = 0.05 hr.
  • Half-life = t1/2 = 0.693/k
  • Therefore t1/2 = 0.693/0.05 =13.8 hrs.
     

Educational Objective:

 

The half-life of a drug with an elimination rate constant of 0.05 hr is 13.8 hours, calculated using the formula t1/2=0.693/k

questions.text: Which among the following IV anaesthetic causes least myocardial depression and maximum hemodynamic stability? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Etomidate

 

  • Among the options given, Etomidate is unique in that it causes minimal cardiovascular depression.
  • This makes it particularly useful in patients with compromised cardiac function or hemodynamic instability
  • Etomidate is an imidazoline derivative used for IV anaesthesia induction, and it offers several advantages:
    • Low risk of myocardial depression
    • Hemodynamic stability on bolus injection

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propofol: Propofol can cause myocardial depression, leading to a decrease in blood pressure. It also produces vasodilation which can further lower blood pressure.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: Thiopentone can cause myocardial depression, leading to a decrease in cardiac output and blood pressure. It also has a vasodilatory effect which can further compromise hemodynamics.

 

Option D. Ketamine: Unlike most other anesthetics, Ketamine typically has a stimulatory effect on the cardiovascular system. It often increases heart rate and blood pressure due to its sympathetic stimulatory effects. However, in patients with depleted catecholamines or in certain pathological conditions, it might not exhibit this stimulatory effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol and Thiopentone are known to cause myocardial depression, Etomidate is recognized for its minimal cardiovascular depression, and Ketamine typically stimulates the cardiovascular system, but with certain exceptions.

questions.text: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

The above image shows formal ether sedimentation technique.

 

Sedimentation techniques use solutions of lower specific gravity than the parasitic organisms, thus concentrating the latter in the sediment. It takes advantage of the high specific gravity of protozoan cysts and helminth eggs compared to water. Their natural tendency to settle out in aqueous solutions can be accelerated by light centrifugation.

 

Formalin fixes the eggs, larvae, oocysts, and spores, so that they are no longer infectious, as well as preserves their morphology. Fecal debris is extracted into the ethyl acetate phase of the solution. Parasitic elements are sedimented at the bottom.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. A: This level contains ether, which is used to extract fecal debris and is found at the top of the tube after centrifugation.

 

Option B. B: This level contains the plug of debris, which is a layer of waste material that is separated from the parasitic elements and sits below the ether layer.

 

Option C. C: This level contains formalin, which fixes and preserves the morphology of the parasitic elements. The formalin layer sits above the sediment but below the plug of debris.

 

Educational Objective

 

In the formal ether sedimentation technique, parasitic ova, cysts, and larvae will be concentrated in the sediment at the bottom of the tube, labeled as level D. This sediment is where parasitic elements are found and examined under a microscope.

questions.text: In which muscles are white fibers predominantly found? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Hand muscles

 

Explanation:


White fibers correspond to Type IIB/Fast Glycolytic muscle fibers. These fibers have high glycolytic capacity but low oxidative capacity. They are characterized by fast contraction speed, high myosin ATPase activity, and rapid fatigue. Hand muscles predominantly contain these white (Type IIB) fibers to facilitate precise, rapid movements required for fine motor skills.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Calf muscle: Calf muscles (particularly soleus) predominantly contain Type I and Type IIA fibers, which are red in color due to higher myoglobin content and greater capillary density. The soleus specifically is noted for containing Type IIA fibers (Fast Oxidative Glycolytic).
  • Option b. Back muscles: Back muscles primarily contain Type I (Slow Oxidative) fibers that appear red due to high myoglobin content. These muscles are responsible for maintaining posture and require sustained contractions rather than rapid, powerful ones.
  • Option c. Gluteal muscles: While gluteal muscles contain a mixture of fiber types, they don't predominantly feature white Type IIB fibers. They have a significant proportion of Type I and Type IIA fibers to support both postural maintenance and powerful movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type IIB/Fast Glycolytic (white) muscle fibers predominate in hand muscles and other muscles requiring rapid, precise movements with short bursts of activity, reflecting their high glycolytic capacity, fast contraction speed, and quick fatigue properties.

choices.text: Duration of action is longer than filgrastim
Added advantage is that it can be taken orally
It is contraindicated in patients with sickle cell anemia
It is not effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pegylated-filgrastim? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duration of action is longer than filgrastim

 

  • Pegylated-filgrastim, also known as peg-filgrastim, is a long-acting formulation of filgrastim that is used to stimulate the production of white blood cells in patients receiving chemotherapy. The addition of polyethylene glycol (PEG) to filgrastim increases its molecular weight and slows down its clearance from the body, resulting in a longer duration of action compared to normal filgrastim.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Added advantage is that it can be taken orally:  Pegylated-filgrastim cannot be taken orally, as it is administered by injection.

 

Option C. It is contraindicated in patients with sickle cell anemia: Pegylated-filgrastim is not contraindicated in sickle cell patients, but caution should be exercised as it can stimulate the production of white blood cells, increasing the risk of sickling crises.

 

Option D. It is not effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia: Pegylated-filgrastim is effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia and can help to reduce the risk of infection in patients undergoing chemotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pegylated-filgrastim has a longer duration of action than regular filgrastim due to its pegylation, which slows its clearance from the body. It is effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia and is administered by injection, not orally. While not contraindicated in sickle cell anemia, caution is advised due to the potential risk of stimulating white blood cell production and increasing the risk of sickling crises.

choices.text: Covers the active site on actin

questions.text: Which attribute accurately describes myosin within muscle fibers? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Exhibits ATPase activity

 

Explanation:

 

Myosin forms the thick filaments in muscle and possesses ATPase activity in its globular head region. The myosin head contains both an actin-binding site and a catalytic site that hydrolyzes ATP. This ATPase activity is essential for the power stroke during muscle contraction, as ATP hydrolysis provides the energy needed for the conformational change in the myosin head that generates force.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Component of thin filaments: Myosin constitutes the thick filaments, not the thin filaments. The thin filaments are composed of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin.
  • Option b. Covers the active site on actin: This is the function of tropomyosin, not myosin. Tropomyosin covers the myosin-binding sites on actin during muscle relaxation, and is displaced when calcium binds to troponin C.
  • Option d. Calcium-binding protein: Calcium binding is the function of troponin C, not myosin. Troponin C contains specific binding sites for calcium that initiate the contractile process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myosin's ATPase activity is fundamental to muscle contraction as it hydrolyzes ATP to generate the energy needed for the power stroke, which creates movement by changing the angle of the myosin head while attached to actin.

questions.text: In a patient with suspected endocrine dysfunction, which hormone primarily acts through the signaling pathway shown in the diagram below, potentially contributing to the patient's condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leptin

 

The provided image depicts the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, known for its association with tyrosine kinase receptors. Within this pathway, leptin operates as one of the hormones involved. Leptin binds to its receptor, activating the JAK-STAT signaling cascade. This pathway is crucial for regulating energy balance and body weight, and its dysfunction can lead to endocrine and metabolic disorders. Leptin's role in this pathway highlights its importance in physiological processes and potential involvement in the patient's endocrine dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcitonin: Calcitonin primarily uses a different signaling mechanism involving G-protein-coupled receptors, not the JAK-STAT pathway.

 

Option C. Vasopressin: Vasopressin operates through G-protein-coupled receptors, particularly influencing water reabsorption in the kidneys, and does not utilize the JAK-STAT signaling pathway.

 

Option D. Aldosterone: Aldosterone acts mainly through mineralocorticoid receptors, influencing sodium and potassium balance in the kidneys, and is not involved in the JAK-STAT signaling pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following physiological adaptations is generally not observed at high altitudes? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis

 

The physiological adaptation that does not happen at high altitudes is respiratory acidosis. Respiratory alkalosis is the physiological adaptation seen at high altitudes due to hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary vasoconstriction: Correct, as it is a physiological response to low oxygen levels to improve gas exchange.

 

Option B. Polycythemia: Correct, as it increases the blood's oxygen-carrying capacity.

 

Option D. Hypoxia: Correct, as it is the primary condition caused by low oxygen levels at high altitudes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The principal means by which acclimatization to high altitude comes about are

 

  1. A great increase in pulmonary ventilation - increase in pulmonary ventilation on rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of carbon dioxide, reducing the Pco2 and increasing the ph of the body fluids.
  2. Increased numbers of red blood cells,
  3. Increased diffusing capacity of the lungs,
  4. Increased vascularity of the peripheral tissues
  5. Increased ability of the tissue cells to use oxygen despite low Po2.
  6. Cellular Acclimatization - cell mitochondria and cellular oxidative enzyme systems are slightly more plentiful than in sea-level inhabitants

choices.text: Binding of Oxygen to hemoglobin reduces its affinity for carbon dioxide
Binding of Oxygen to hemoglobin makes it more acidic
Deoxygenated hemoglobin binds more hydrogen ions
Decrease in blood pH results in a lower affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen

questions.text: Which of the following statements does NOT accurately describe the Haldane Effect? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Decrease in blood pH results in a lower affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen.

 

Explanation:

 

The Haldane effect specifically refers to the increased capacity of deoxygenated hemoglobin to bind and carry CO₂ compared to oxygenated hemoglobin. When hemoglobin releases oxygen in the tissues, it becomes better at binding CO₂ and H⁺. Conversely, when hemoglobin binds oxygen in the lungs, it releases CO₂ more readily. Statement D describes the Bohr effect (where decreased pH reduces oxygen binding), not the Haldane effect, making it the incorrect statement.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Binding of Oxygen to hemoglobin reduces its affinity for carbon dioxide - This correctly describes the Haldane effect. When hemoglobin binds O₂ in the lungs, it releases CO₂ more easily, facilitating CO₂ excretion.
  • Option B. Binding of Oxygen to hemoglobin makes it more acidic - This statement is accurate. Oxygenated hemoglobin is a stronger acid than deoxygenated hemoglobin because its imidazole groups dissociate more readily.
  • Option C. Deoxygenated hemoglobin binds more hydrogen ions - This is correct and essential to the Haldane effect. Deoxygenated hemoglobin has a greater capacity to bind H⁺ ions, making it a better buffer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Haldane effect (increased CO₂ carrying capacity of deoxygenated blood) and Bohr effect (decreased O₂ affinity with lower pH) are complementary but distinct physiological mechanisms that optimize gas exchange in tissues and lungs.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with complaints of progressive loss of vision in the right halves of both eyes. Where is the lesion located in the optic pathway? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

 

The patient presenting with progressive visual loss in the right halves of both eyes is suggestive of right homonymous hemianopia. The site of the lesion in this case is the left optic tract.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right visual cortex: Lesions in the right visual cortex would cause left homonymous hemianopia, not right. The visual cortex processes information from the contralateral visual field.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma: Lesions in the optic chiasma typically cause bitemporal hemianopia, which is the loss of the outer (temporal) visual fields in both eyes. This is due to the crossing fibers from the nasal retinas.

 

Option D. Right optic nerve: A lesion in the right optic nerve would cause vision loss in the right eye only, not in both eyes. It would not result in a homonymous visual field defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right homonymous hemianopia, characterized by loss of the right visual field in both eyes, is caused by a lesion in the left optic tract.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Morphine is used for treatment of pulmonary oedema
  2. Pethidine is used for treatment of pain due to biliary colic
  3. Indomethacin can cause headache
  4. Aspirin is used for treatment of peptic ulcer disease
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A and C

 

Aspirin can actually exacerbate peptic ulcer disease due to its mechanism of inhibiting prostaglandin production, which is protective for the gastric mucosa. It is more commonly associated with causing or worsening gastric ulcers rather than treating them.

 

A. Morphine is used for treatment of pulmonary edema: Morphine can be used in the acute management of pulmonary edema, particularly when it's due to heart failure. It reduces preload and afterload on the heart and can alleviate the associated anxiety and discomfort. However, its use has become less common due to concerns about potential side effects, including respiratory depression.

 

C. Indomethacin can cause headache: This is true. While Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to treat pain, inflammation, and fever, one of its side effects can be headache.

 

Other options:

 

B. Pethidine is used for treatment of pain due to biliary colic: Pethidine (Meperidine) is generally not recommended for biliary colic because it can cause spasm of the sphincter of Oddi, potentially worsening pain in biliary coli due to its anticholinergic property.

 

D. Aspirin is used for treatment of peptic ulcer disease: This is false. Aspirin can actually exacerbate peptic ulcer disease due to its mechanism of inhibiting prostaglandin production, which protects the gastric mucosa. Aspirin is more commonly associated with causing or worsening gastric ulcers rather than treating them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Morphine can be used for the treatment of pulmonary edema, and indomethacin can cause headaches.
  • Aspirin is not used for the treatment of peptic ulcer disease and can actually worsen it. While opioids can be used for biliary colic, their use is not without complications, and not all opioids are appropriate for this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is Burkholderia cepacia resistant to? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cefotetan

 

Burkholderia cepacia complex is known for its intrinsic resistance to various antimicrobial agents, including cefotetan.

 

B. Cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to:

 

  • Aminoglycosides
  • Polymixin
  • First and second-generation cephalosporins
  • Carboxypenicillins

 

B. Cepacia can cause severe necrotizing pneumonia in patients with chronic granulomatous disease. It can lead to fatal septicemia in patients with cystic fibrosis.

 

Antimicrobial agents that are effective against B. cepacia complex include:

 

  • Meropenem
  • Ceftazidime
  • Piperacillin
  • Temocillin
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ceftazidime: Incorrect because ceftazidime is actually among the antimicrobials that are effective against B. cepacia complex, suggesting it can bypass the bacterium’s resistance mechanisms.

 

Option B. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: Incorrect, as this combination is also effective against B. cepacia, demonstrating its capability to treat infections caused by this pathogen.

 

Option C. Temocillin: Incorrect, as temocillin is listed as effective against B. cepacia complex, indicating its efficacy in combating this resistant bacterium.

 

Educational Objective

 

Burkholderia cepacia exhibits resistance to several antibiotic classes, including second-generation cephalosporins like cefotetan.

choices.text: 30 minutes
60 minutes
90 minutes

questions.text: A patient is on phenytoin for a seizure disorder. He was prescribed sucralfate 4 times a day for peptic ulcers. What should be the minimum duration of time between consumption of these drugs? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 120 minutes

 

  • Sucralfate is made up of aluminium octosulphate of sucrose. In the acidic pH of the stomach, it gets polymerized into a viscous fluid which adheres to the base of the ulcer for upto 6 hours. However, this viscous layer prevents the absorption of other drugs like phenytoin, ketoconazole, fluoroquinolones etc. from the stomach.
  • When a patient is taking both phenytoin (an antiepileptic drug) and sucralfate (a medication used to treat peptic ulcers), it's important to manage the timing of these medications to avoid drug interactions.
  • Sucralfate can interfere with the absorption of phenytoin when taken too closely together, leading to reduced effectiveness of phenytoin.
  • The general recommendation is to separate the administration of these two drugs by at least 2 hours. This separation allows sufficient time for the phenytoin to be absorbed before the sucralfate is taken, which can bind to drugs in the gastrointestinal tract and hinder their absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum duration of time between the consumption of phenytoin and sucralfate should be at least 120 minutes (2 hours) to ensure that phenytoin is adequately absorbed and to avoid interactions that could reduce its effectiveness.

choices.text: EMLA means equal mixture of LA
Methemoglobinemia is a complication of this cream
1 gm of 5% cream contains lignocaine 50mg

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methemoglobinemia is a complication of this cream 

 

The cream shown in the image is EMLA cream, which is a topical anesthetic. EMLA cream contains a combination of two local anesthetics, lidocaine and prilocaine, in a 1:1 ratio. One of the known complications of EMLA cream is methemoglobinemia. This condition can occur, especially when the cream is used in large quantities or in patients with certain predispositions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EMLA means equal mixture of LA: EMLA means Eutectic mixture of LA and not equal mixture of LA.

 

Option B. It contains lignocaine and ropivacaine: This option is incorrect because EMLA cream does not contain ropivacaine. The active ingredients in EMLA cream are lidocaine (lignocaine) and prilocaine.

 

Option D. 1 gm of 5% cream contains lignocaine 50mg: This option is also incorrect. 1 gram of EMLA 5% cream contains 25mg of lidocaine and 25mg of prilocaine, not 50mg of lidocaine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EMLA cream can cause methemoglobinemia as a complication, especially when used inappropriately or in large quantities.

questions.text: Identify the range of the firearm wound: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Close Shot Entry Wound

 

  • Lot of blackening is easily visible around the firearm wound in the image.
  • Burning, blackening and tattooing are the features of entry wound. They are not found in exit wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Close shot exit wound: Exit wounds typically do not exhibit burning, blackening, or tattooing. They are generally larger and more irregular than entry wounds.

 

Option C. Distant shot entry wound: Distant shot entry wounds lack the features of burning, blackening, and tattooing. The wound edges are usually cleaner.

 

Option D. Distant shot exit wound: Similar to close shot exit wounds, distant shot exit wounds do not have burning, blackening, or tattooing and are typically larger and more irregular.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

questions.text: Which protein is present in the HPV vaccine? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1

 

9-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil-9) is a non-infectious recombinant vaccine prepared from the purified virus-like particles (VLPs) of the major capsid (L1) protein of HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

 

Available HPV vaccines protect against either two, four, or nine types of HPV. All HPV vaccines protect against at least HPV types 16 and 18, which cause the greatest risk of cervical cancer. It is estimated that HPV vaccines may prevent 70% of cervical cancer, 80% of anal cancer, 60% of vaginal cancer, 40% of vulvar cancer, and show more than 90% efficacy in preventing HPV-positive oropharyngeal cancers. They additionally prevent some genital warts, with the quadrivalent and nonavalent vaccines that protect against HPV types HPV-6 and HPV-11 providing greater protection.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. E6, E7: These proteins are oncogenes that contribute to the development of cancer by interfering with tumor suppressor proteins such as p53 and Rb but are not components of the vaccine.

 

Option C. E1, E2: These are early proteins involved in the replication and regulation of HPV DNA but are not used in the vaccine formulation.

 

Option D. L2: This is a minor capsid protein of HPV, but the vaccine primarily uses the major capsid protein L1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine contains the L1 protein, which forms virus-like particles that induce an immune response to prevent infection by various HPV types, significantly reducing the risk of HPV-associated cancers and genital warts.

questions.text: A five-year-old child presents with pustular lesions on the lower legs. The culture from the lesions shows hemolytic gram-positive cocci. Which test would best aid in the provisional diagnosis of Group A streptococcal pyoderma? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Bacitracin sensitivity

 

Explanation:

 

Bacitracin sensitivity is the most appropriate test for identifying Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) from the pustular lesions. Group A streptococci are characteristically sensitive to bacitracin, which serves as a key identifying feature in the laboratory. This susceptibility pattern helps differentiate S. pyogenes from other beta-hemolytic streptococci, particularly Group B streptococci which are typically resistant to bacitracin. In the clinical context of a child with pustular skin lesions and isolation of beta-hemolytic gram-positive cocci, the bacitracin sensitivity test is an essential diagnostic tool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase positive test - This is incorrect because streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are catalase negative. The catalase test is primarily used to differentiate staphylococci (catalase positive) from streptococci (catalase negative). While Staphylococcus species can cause pustular skin lesions, the question specifically asks about diagnosing Group A streptococcal pyoderma.

 

Option B. Optochin sensitivity - This is incorrect because optochin sensitivity is used specifically for identifying Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococci). Group A streptococci are not characteristically sensitive to optochin. This test helps differentiate pneumococci from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci but is not useful for identifying beta-hemolytic Group A streptococci.

 

Option C. Bile solubility - This is incorrect because the bile solubility test is specific for Streptococcus pneumoniae. Pneumococci are soluble in bile while other streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are not. This test is not used in the identification of beta-hemolytic streptococci causing skin infections.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bacitracin sensitivity testing is a critical diagnostic tool for the presumptive identification of Group A Streptococcus (S. pyogenes) in clinical specimens, with sensitivity to bacitracin differentiating it from other beta-hemolytic streptococci, particularly Group B streptococci which are typically resistant.

choices.text: Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors
Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate
Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane

questions.text: Mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants is?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors 

 

  • The curare group of muscle relaxants are non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents.
  • These drugs act by binding to the acetylcholine (ACh) receptors at the neuromuscular junction without activating them.
  • This competitive inhibition prevents acetylcholine from binding to its receptors, thereby inhibiting the action of acetylcholine and leading to muscle paralysis.
  • This prevents the muscle from contracting, resulting in muscle relaxation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Persistently depolarizing at neuromuscular junction: This describes depolarizing muscle relaxants, such as succinylcholine, which bind to and open the acetylcholine receptors on the muscle endplate. This causes a prolonged depolarization and prevents the muscle from repolarizing, thereby causing paralysis.

 

Option C. Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate: This does not describe the mechanism of any muscle relaxant. Persistent or repetitive stimulation would cause sustained depolarization leading to muscle paralysis, but this is not how the curare group works.

 

Option D. Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane: Some drugs inhibit calcium channels, preventing the release of neurotransmitters, including acetylcholine. However, this is not the mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The curare group of muscle relaxants work by competitively blocking the binding of acetylcholine to its receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle paralysis.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 779

questions.text: What is the mechanism of oxygen delivery of the following device? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Venturi effect

 

Venturi Mask:

 

  • Definition: The image shows a Venturi mask, an oxygen delivery device that utilizes the Venturi effect.
  • Mechanism:

 

The Venturi effect occurs when fluid (in this case, air) is passed through a constricted section of a pipe, increasing its velocity and causing a decrease in lateral pressure. This drop in pressure entrains the surrounding air into the main flow. The Venturi mask uses this principle to mix ambient air with pure oxygen, providing a fixed and predetermined concentration of oxygen to the patient.

 

  • Application:
    • The mask has different colored valves, each corresponding to a specific oxygen concentration.
    • The Venturi effect ensures that each valve delivers a consistent mix of room air and oxygen, regardless of the patient's breathing rate.
    • This precise oxygen delivery is crucial for patients who require a specific FiO2 (fraction of inspired oxygen).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Photoelectric Effect:

  • Definition: The photoelectric effect involves the emission of electrons from a material when it is exposed to light.
  • Usage: It has no application in the mechanism of oxygen delivery.

 

Option B. Bernoulli Effect:

  • Definition: The Bernoulli effect states that an increase in the speed of a fluid occurs simultaneously with a decrease in pressure or potential energy.
  • Usage: Although related to fluid dynamics, it does not specifically describe the mechanism used in the Venturi mask.

 

Option D. Boyle's Law:

  • Definition: Boyle's law describes the relationship between the pressure and volume of a gas at constant temperature (P1V1 = P2V2).
  • Usage: It is a fundamental gas law but does not directly relate to the mechanism of oxygen delivery in a Venturi mask.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Venturi mask utilizes the Venturi effect to deliver a precise and consistent concentration of oxygen by mixing ambient air with pure oxygen. This principle ensures the patient receives the required FiO2, crucial for managing specific respiratory conditions.

questions.text: A man wears female heels and a female dress to get sexual arousal. He is not interested in males. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transvestic Fetishism

 

Transvestic Fetishism is a condition where an individual wears clothing of the opposite sex primarily to achieve sexual arousal. The key aspect of this disorder is the act of cross-dressing for the purpose of sexual gratification, not because of a desire to be of the opposite gender or any issues with gender identity. The patient described is not interested in males and is engaging in cross-dressing purely for sexual arousal, fitting the diagnosis of Transvestic Fetishism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gender Dysphoria: Gender Dysphoria involves a conflict between an individual’s biological sex and their gender identity, such as a biologically male person identifying as female or vice versa. There is no indication in this case of any gender identity issues; the patient cross-dresses purely for sexual arousal.

 

Option C. Homosexuality: Homosexuality refers to a sexual orientation characterized by attraction to individuals of the same sex. The scenario explicitly states that the man is not interested in males, ruling out homosexuality as the correct diagnosis.

 

Option D. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is the act of gaining sexual pleasure from watching others when they are naked or engaged in sexual activity, usually without their knowledge or consent. There is no element of voyeuristic behavior described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transvestic Fetishism is characterized by cross-dressing for sexual arousal without any associated desire to change one’s gender or sexual orientation.

questions.text: Which law states that the amount of pressure exerted by a gas in a mixture is proportional to the percentage of the gas in the mixture? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Dalton's law

 

Explanation: 

 

Dalton's law states that in a gas mixture, each individual gas exerts a partial pressure that is directly proportional to its percentage composition in the mixture. The formula PP = % Gas × Total pressure directly reflects Dalton's law, where each gas contributes to the total atmospheric pressure based on its fractional concentration. For example, at sea level with atmospheric pressure of 760 mmHg, oxygen (21%) exerts 160 mmHg, nitrogen (79%) exerts 600 mmHg, and CO₂ (0.04%) exerts 0.3 mmHg - each proportional to their respective percentages.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Graham's law - This law relates to the rate of diffusion of gases being inversely proportional to the square root of their molecular weights, not about pressure relationships in gas mixtures.
  • Option C. Henry's law - Henry's law specifically states that "gases that dissolve in the blood only they can generate the partial pressure in the blood." This law governs gas solubility in liquids, not the pressure exerted by gases in mixtures.
  • Option D. Boyle's law - Boyle's law is defined as P ∝ 1/V (pressure inversely proportional to volume). This law describes the relationship between pressure and volume of a gas at constant temperature, not the pressure contribution of individual gases in a mixture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dalton's law is fundamental to understanding respiratory gas exchange, as it explains how each respiratory gas (O₂, CO₂, N₂) contributes its specific partial pressure to the total atmospheric pressure based on its percentage composition.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state.
  • TED may be associated with Graves’ disease, hypothyroidism, or euthyroidism, and the direct causative connection between thyroid dysfunction and ocular changes is unclear.
  • Main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with painful eye movements, periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia.

 

Option C. Orbital lymphoma: Usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.

 

Option D. Orbital cellulitis: Is usually U/L condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis

 

NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

THYROID OPHTHALMOPATHY EYE SIGNS:

  1. Stellwag sign- incomplete and frequent blinking
  2. Gifford sign- difficulty while everting the upper eyelid
  3. Jellinek sign- abnormal pigmentation of upper eyelid
  4. Enroth sign- lower eyelid edema
  5. Griffith sign- lid lag on upgaze
  6. Mobius sign- not able to converge eyes
  7. Ballet's sign- one or more extraocular muscle restriction
  8. Von graefe sign- retarded descent of upper lid in downgaze
  9. Joffrey sign- absent crease of the forehead in superior gaze
  10. Kocher's sign- staring and frightened appearance of eyes
  11. Dalyrymple sign- eyelid retraction

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male who was a tattoo artist was brought dead to the casualty under mysterious circumstances. His girlfriend reported he had a large tattoo on his right hand, but this was not found on examination. Which structure should be examined to get more idea of the same? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymph nodes

 

The ink used for making a tattoo mark is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Thus, if there is natural / iatrogenic tattoo removal the lymph nodes must be examined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver: The liver is involved in the detoxification and metabolism of substances, but it is not directly related to the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen filters blood and is involved in immune responses, but it does not play a role in the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option D. Skin: The skin is the primary site where tattoos are applied. However, in the case of a removed tattoo, the skin may not provide useful information about the former presence of the tattoo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examining the regional lymph nodes can reveal traces of tattoo ink even if the tattoo itself is no longer visible on the skin, providing useful forensic evidence.

choices.text: Inside the membrane
At the C-terminal
At the N-terminal
Both inside the membrane and at C- terminal

questions.text: The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein with N-terminal facing cytoplasm is located in?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inside the membrane

 

The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein is located inside the membrane.

 

These sequences usually have methionine as the terminal amino acid.

 

Transmembrane proteins are integral proteins that span across the plasma/ endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane. They are classified into types 1 to 4. –

 

Type 1 membrane proteins have a cleavable N-terminal signal sequence outside the cell, a transmembrane sequence that is usually situated close to the C-terminus and the C-terminus facing inside the cell, e.g., low-density lipoprotein receptor.

 

Type 2 membrane proteins have the N-terminal towards the cytosol and the C-terminal towards the exterior, e.g., transferrin receptor.

 

Type 3 membrane proteins are identical to type 1 but have a shorter N terminal, e.g., cytochrome P450 enzyme complexes.

 

Type 4 membrane proteins consist of 7 alpha helices traversing the membrane, e.g., glucose transporters and G-protein-coupled receptors.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. At the C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is not located at the C-terminal.

 

Option C. At the N-terminal: This is incorrect as well. In type 2 membrane proteins, the N-terminal is facing the cytoplasm, but the signaling sequence itself is located inside the membrane.

 

Option D. Both inside the membrane and at C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence is located specifically inside the membrane, not at the C-terminal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is located inside the membrane, crucial for the proper orientation and insertion of the protein.

choices.text: Reducing fluid intake to <500 ml per day

questions.text: The best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tolvaptan

 

The best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) is to use tolvaptan.

 

Tolvaptan is a selective vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist that works by blocking the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in the kidneys, leading to increased urine output and improved serum sodium levels. It is currently the preferred treatment for chronic SIADH, as it has been shown to be effective in improving symptoms and reducing the risk of complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reducing fluid intake to <500 ml per day is not a recommended approach to treating chronic SIADH, as it can lead to dehydration and other complications.

 

Option C. Demeclocycline, a tetracycline antibiotic, is another treatment option for SIADH, but it is less effective and has more side effects compared to tolvaptan.

 

Option D. Fludrocortisone, a mineralocorticoid hormone, is not recommended for the treatment of SIADH, as it can worsen hyponatremia (low sodium levels) and increase the risk of fluid retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tolvaptan is the best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH due to its selective antagonism of the vasopressin V2 receptor, leading to increased urine output and improved serum sodium levels. Other methods, such as severe fluid restriction and demeclocycline, are less effective or have more side effects. Fludrocortisone is not suitable for treating SIADH and can exacerbate the condition.

questions.text: What is basiliximab? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IL-2 receptor antagonist

 

Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets and binds with high affinity to the IL-2 receptor, also known as CD25, on the surface of activated T-cells. By antagonizing this receptor, basiliximab inhibits the proliferation of T-cells that are critical for the immune response, thereby helping to prevent transplant rejection. It is commonly used in combination with other immunosuppressive agents to prevent acute rejection in organ transplantation, particularly kidney transplants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL-1 receptor antagonist: IL-1 receptor antagonists, such as anakinra, target the IL-1 receptor and are used in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis. Basiliximab does not target the IL-1 receptor.

 

Option B. Anti-CD3 antibody: Anti-CD3 antibodies, such as muromonab-CD3, target the CD3 receptor on T-cells and are used for acute transplant rejection. Basiliximab, however, is not an anti-CD3 antibody.

 

Option D. TNF inhibitor: TNF inhibitors, such as infliximab and adalimumab, target tumor necrosis factor (TNF) and are used in autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and Crohn's disease. Basiliximab does not inhibit TNF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basiliximab is an IL-2 receptor antagonist that binds to the CD25 receptor on activated T-cells, thereby preventing T-cell proliferation and helping to prevent transplant rejection reactions. It is specifically used in the context of organ transplantation to reduce the risk of acute rejection.

questions.text: Colour for Nitrous Oxide Cylinder in India is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blue

 

Nitrous oxide is stored in blue color cylinders at a pressure of 760 psi. The standardized color coding system for medical gas cylinders follows Indian Standards adopted on November 24, 1966. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. White: White shoulders with a black body is the color coding for oxygen cylinders. Oxygen cylinders have a pressure of 2,000 psi and are typically available in various sizes (smallest AA, largest H, with type E commonly mounted on anesthesia machines).

 

Option C. Gray: Gray is the color used for carbon dioxide cylinders. Carbon dioxide was stored at a pressure of 750 psi in liquid form but is no longer commonly used in anesthesia.

 

Option D. Brown: Brown shoulders (combined with black and white) are used for helium-containing mixtures like Heliox, which consists of 79% helium and 21% oxygen stored in black cylinders with brown and white shoulders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical gas cylinder color coding is a critical safety mechanism - nitrous oxide cylinders are distinctively blue, stored at 760 psi, and their contents are measured by weight rather than pressure because the gas exists in liquid form inside the cylinder.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an endocrine change associated with protein-energy malnutrition? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Low cortisol

 

Explanation: 

 

In protein-energy malnutrition (PEM), the body undergoes specific hormonal adaptations to conserve energy and maintain essential functions. Cortisol, being a stress hormone, actually increases in malnutrition (not decreases). This elevated cortisol helps mobilize amino acids from muscle tissue, stimulates gluconeogenesis in the liver, and maintains blood glucose levels during nutritional stress—all critical survival mechanisms during starvation.

The theory of adaptation in malnutrition explains these hormonal changes as the body's attempt to prioritize vital functions while reducing energy expenditure on growth and other non-essential processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low insulin - CORRECT finding in PEM. Insulin secretion decreases to minimize glucose uptake by peripheral tissues and maintain blood glucose for brain function.

 

Option C. Low thyroid hormone - CORRECT finding in PEM. Thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) decrease, resulting in reduced basal metabolic rate and oxygen consumption as an energy-sparing adaptation.

 

Option D. Elevated growth hormone - CORRECT finding in PEM. Despite increased growth hormone levels, there is peripheral resistance to its action and decreased production of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), explaining the growth failure despite high GH levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Protein-energy malnutrition produces a characteristic endocrine profile with elevated stress hormones (cortisol), decreased anabolic hormones (insulin, thyroid hormones), and elevated but ineffective growth hormone—all serving to conserve energy and maintain vital functions during nutritional deprivation.

choices.text: Pulmonary edema
Congestive cardiac failure
Acute kidney injury with anuria

questions.text: Intravenous mannitol is used in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glaucoma

 

Intravenous mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that is often used in emergency situations to lower intraocular pressure in acute congestive glaucoma. It works by drawing fluid out of the eye, thereby reducing pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary Edema: Mannitol is not used for pulmonary edema. Diuretics like furosemide are more commonly used in such cases to remove excess fluid from the lungs.

 

Option B. Congestive Cardiac Failure: Mannitol is not used in congestive cardiac failure. Loop diuretics like furosemide or thiazide diuretics are more commonly used to reduce fluid overload in these patients.

 

Option C. Acute Kidney Injury with Anuria: Mannitol is contraindicated in cases of anuria due to acute kidney injury. The drug could potentially worsen renal function in such cases.

 

Therefore, intravenous mannitol is used for acute cases of glaucoma to reduce intraocular pressure, making option D the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective

 

Intravenous mannitol is specifically used in acute cases of glaucoma to rapidly reduce intraocular pressure by drawing fluid out of the eye. It is not used for conditions like pulmonary edema, congestive cardiac failure, or acute kidney injury with anuria, where other diuretics are more appropriate and effective.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman was involved in a car accident two months ago, and she now complains of screaming and waking up in the middle of the night after having nightmares about the same incident over and over. Which of the following conditions does she have? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post traumatic stress disorder

 

This woman's presentation of recurrent nightmares about a traumatic event (the car accident) that happened two months ago suggests Post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). PTSD can develop after a traumatic event and involves symptoms such as re-experiencing the trauma (e.g., flashbacks, nightmares), avoidance of reminders of the trauma, negative alterations in mood and cognition, and increased arousal (e.g., irritability, difficulty sleeping).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute stress reaction: Acute stress reaction typically occurs immediately after a traumatic event and lasts for a few days to a few weeks.

 

Option B. Adjustment disorder: Adjustment disorder develops in response to a stressor and is characterized by emotional and behavioral symptoms, rather than the nightmares. It arises within three months of the stressor.

 

Option C. Mania: Mania is characterized by elevated mood, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep, among other symptoms, and isn't directly related to a traumatic event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PTSD manifests after experiencing or witnessing significant traumatic event, with symptoms like flashbacks, nightmares,hypervigilance, exaggerated startle response,  severe anxiety centered on the event and avoidance of the situations that remind of the trauma. The symptoms must be present for at least one month. It is more common in females and young adults. Hippocampus and amygdala are implicated in the etiology of PTSD. Treatment includes trauma-focussed CBT (treatment of choice), SSRIs (Drug of choice), and eye movements desensitization and reprocessing.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 439-441.

questions.text: A vagabond roaming in the forest eats some unknown fruits. After sometime he starts having symptoms of irritability, restlessness, dry hot skin, and was unable to pass urine and stools. Identify the poison and its appropriate antidote: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

Diagnostic features of Datura poisoning in the question

 

  • Datura has mainly neurotoxic (Irritability, restlessness) and anticholinergic features (Dry hot skin, unable to urinate and pass stool)
  • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice for Datura

 

Datura poisoning:

 

  • Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.
  • Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.
  • Features of Datura poisoning (D's of Datura): Dry hot skin, Dilatation of pupils, Diplopia, Dry mouth, Dysphagia, Dysarthria, Drunken gait, Delirium, Drowsiness, Death.
  • Datura causes constipation, not diarrhoea

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning:

 

  • Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug.
  • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice
  • Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is used for organophosphate poisoning, not for anticholinergic toxicity caused by Datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Digoxin: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside and not an antidote. The treatment for yellow oleander poisoning includes atropine and antiarrhythmics, not digoxin.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Physostigmine is not the antidote for yellow oleander poisoning, which primarily affects the heart rather than causing anticholinergic symptoms.

 

Additional Information

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • There are two oleander plants: Nerium odorum and Cerbera Thevetia
  • Both are cardiac poisons
  • Both have digoxin like toxicity:
    • Heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse).
    • Similar to digitalis.
    •  Muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning.
  • Treatment of Both Oleander poisoning:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies for severe arrhythmias

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Datura poisoning is characterized by neurotoxic and anticholinergic symptoms, and the appropriate antidote is Physostigmine, which can cross the blood-brain barrier and reverse CNS toxicity.

questions.text: The image given below shows neuromuscular monitoring of the patient after anesthesia. What is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ulnar nerve

 

  • To monitor adequacy of neuromuscular blockade ulnar nerve is preferred.
  • It is monitored using a Train of Four monitor/peripheral nerve stimulator.
  • Twitching of the adductor pollicis muscle is seen on electrical stimulation of the ulnar nerve.
  • The ulnar nerve is frequently used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade during and after anesthesia.
  • It is typically monitored using a device known as a Train of Four (TOF) monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator.
  • The ulnar nerve is accessible and provides a reliable location for monitoring. Twitching of the adductor pollicis muscle (a muscle in the thumb) is commonly observed when electrical stimulation is applied to the ulnar nerve.
  • This twitch response is used to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade and the patient's recovery from anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median nerve: While the median nerve can be used for neuromuscular monitoring, the ulnar nerve is more commonly preferred because of its accessibility and ease of stimulation. The adductor pollicis muscle twitch response is typically more reliable for assessing neuromuscular blockade compared to other muscles.

 

Option C. Radial nerve: The radial nerve can also be used for neuromuscular monitoring, but it is not as commonly chosen as the ulnar nerve. Similar to the median nerve, the ulnar nerve offers a more reliable and standard location for monitoring.

 

Option D. Metacarpal nerve: There is no specific nerve called the "metacarpal nerve" commonly used for neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade, typically assessed using a Train of Four (TOF) monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator.

choices.text: A, B & C
A, B, C & D

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in Gout? (INICET Nov 2020)

A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid excretion

B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint

C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways

D. Aspirin is used as it is most powerful NSAID
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A, B & C

 

Options A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid excretion: This statement remains correct. Aspirin at low doses can decrease uric acid excretion, potentially worsening gout. Therefore, it is generally not recommended in the management of gout.

 

Options B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint: Diclofenac is commonly used in the management of gout due to its anti-inflammatory properties. It gets concentrated in joints and its effect in reducing inflammation and pain in gout is beneficial.

 

Options C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways: Indomethacin is indeed used in the treatment of gout. It is an NSAID that works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins. It has multiple pathways of action including inhibition of COX and decrease in rate of phagocytosis of urate crystals.

 

Other Options:

 

Options D. Aspirin is used as it is the most powerful NSAID: This statement is incorrect for reasons previously mentioned. Aspirin, particularly at low doses, is not recommended for gout due to its potential to increase serum uric acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The preferred treatment for an acute gout attack is an NSAID (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug), such as indomethacin.
  • A typical first-line treatment for gout is indomethacin. Besides suppressing prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also reduce rate of crystal phagocytosis.
  • Furthermore, intraarticular steroids like methylprednisolone or triamcinolone may be given.
  • Aspirin is not utilized because it promotes renal retention of uric acid.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ptosis

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of a diagnosis of Myasthenia gravis.

 

  • Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a neuromuscular disorder that affects the cranial muscles, including the lids and extraocular muscles (EOMs).
  • Ptosis and diplopia are common initial complaints in MG.
  • Ptosis is the most common ocular feature in MG.
  • The cranial muscles are typically involved early in the course of MG.
  • If weakness remains restricted to the EOMs for 3 years, it is likely that it will not become generalized.
  • Patients who only experience weakness in the EOMs for 3 years are said to have ocular MG.

 

Tensilon test:

 

In Myasthenia, there is improvement of ptosis with IV inj. of Edrophonium (Tensilon).

 

 

Lagophthalmos and Exophthalmos are signs of Thyroid Eye Disease.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Diplopia: Common in MG but less frequent than ptosis.

 

Option B. Lagophthalmos: Inability to close the eyelids completely, typically associated with thyroid eye disease or facial nerve palsy, not common in MG.

 

Option C. Exophthalmos: Protrusion of the eyeball, commonly seen in thyroid eye disease, not MG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) is the most common ocular finding in Myasthenia Gravis, a neuromuscular disorder characterized by antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following antimicrobials is effective against an organism producing extended-spectrum beta-lactamases? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Piperacillin - tazobactam

 

ESBL is produced by gram-negative organisms like Klebsiella and E. coli. They are resistant to most of the Beta-lactam antibiotics like Penicillin and most of the Cephalosporins. Tazobactam, Sulbactam and Clavulanic acid are beta lactamase inhibitors, hence they can be used against ESBL producing organisms. Therefore, the correct option will be Piperacillin+ Tazobactam combination.

 

Piperacillin-tazobactam is effective against ESBL-producing organisms because tazobactam inhibits the beta-lactamase enzyme, allowing piperacillin to exert its antibacterial effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin - clavulanic acid: Although clavulanic acid is a beta-lactamase inhibitor, the combination of amoxicillin and clavulanic acid is generally less effective against ESBL-producing organisms compared to piperacillin-tazobactam.

 

Option B. Penicillin: Penicillin alone is not effective against ESBL-producing organisms because it is susceptible to degradation by beta-lactamases.

 

Option D. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is generally ineffective against ESBL-producing organisms as they can hydrolyze this class of antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Piperacillin-tazobactam is effective against organisms producing extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs) due to the beta-lactamase inhibitory action of tazobactam, which protects piperacillin from enzymatic degradation, allowing it to kill the bacteria.

questions.text: A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

H/O consumption of a fruit, high fever, confusion, photophobia, unable to urinate are anticholinergic symptoms. Photophobia occurs due to mydriasis in anticholinergic poisoning.

 

Datura poisoning:

 

Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.

 

Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.

 

Features of Datura poisoning:

 

 D's of Datura

 

  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death

 

Datura Flowers: Flowers are large tubular (trumpet-shaped) which may be white (alba) or purple (Niger)

 

Datura Fruit capsule: It is spherical with soft spines and contains 50 to 100 dark brown reniform (kidney-shaped) seeds which bear a superficial resemblance to chilly seeds

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning: Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug, physostigmine [Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity]

 

Below image shows Datura Flower and Datura Fruit

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. While Datura is the correct causative agent, Pralidoxime is not the correct antidote. Pralidoxime is used in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning, not anticholinergic poisoning caused by Datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. Yellow oleander poisoning presents primarily with symptoms of cardiac toxicity, such as arrhythmias and heart failure, not the anticholinergic symptoms described in the question. Additionally, Pralidoxime is used for organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Incorrect. Again, Yellow oleander would cause symptoms related to cardiac toxicity rather than the anticholinergic symptoms presented. Physostigmine is not the antidote for Yellow oleander poisoning.

 

Additional Information

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • Types:
  1. Nerium odorum (White Oleander): Bears white, dark red or pink flowers
  2. Cerbera thevetia (Yellow Oleander): Bears yellow bell-shaped flowers, globular fruits

 

 

  • Symptoms: In both oleanders there will symptoms of heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse) and muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning. They are similar to digitalis causing death from cardiac failure.
  • Treatment:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine is useful in the management of ventricular tachyarrhythmias, premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), and bigeminy.
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies (digoxin-specific Fab fragments) are the treatment of choice for severe bradyarrhythmia’s with hypotension unresponsive to atropine and life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used as an anti-smoking agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Varenicline

 

Varenicline is an FDA-approved medication that helps individuals quit smoking by reducing the craving and withdrawal symptoms associated with tobacco use. It acts as a partial agonist at alpha4 beta2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, which can both stimulate the receptor (to reduce craving) and block nicotine from binding (to reduce the rewarding effects of cigarettes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Busulfan: An alkylating agent used primarily in the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia.

 

Option B. Acamprosate: Used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing the craving for alcohol.

 

Option D. Gabapentin: An anticonvulsant that is also used for neuropathic pain and certain mood disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Varenicline is a partial agonist at α4β2 & α7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. As a partial agonist it prevents high and reinforcement and also controls craving and withdrawal due to tobacco use. It is the most effective agent for tobacco use disorders.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 505.

questions.text: The causative agent for St. Anthony's Fire is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Streptococcus

 

Explanation:

 

St. Anthony's Fire is a historical term that refers to erysipelas, an acute infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics. This condition is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), which is characterized by a bright red, swollen, and indurated skin lesion with a distinct raised border. The condition was named "St. Anthony's Fire" due to the intense burning sensation patients experience and the fiery red appearance of the affected skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Staphylococcus Staphylococcus species, particularly S. aureus, typically cause skin infections such as furuncles, carbuncles, impetigo and wound infections. While they can cause cellulitis, they do not cause the classical erysipelas (St. Anthony's Fire) with its characteristic raised borders and bright red appearance.

 

Option C: Klebsiella Klebsiella is a Gram-negative bacillus of the Enterobacteriaceae family. It is primarily associated with pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and septicemia, particularly in hospitalized patients. It is not associated with erysipelas or St. Anthony's Fire.

 

Option D: Nocardia Nocardia is an aerobic Gram-positive bacterium that causes nocardiosis, which typically presents as a pulmonary infection with possible dissemination to other organs, particularly the brain. It also can cause cutaneous infections, but these typically present as abscesses or mycetomas, not as erysipelas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

St. Anthony's Fire (erysipelas) is a distinctive streptococcal skin infection characterized by sharply demarcated, bright red, indurated lesions with raised borders, caused specifically by Streptococcus pyogenes.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Head tilt, chin lift

 

The maneuver performed in the given image is that of a head-tilt chin-lift. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

 

  • Tilt the patient’s head back by pushing down on the forehead.
  • Place the tips of your index and middle fingers under the chin and pull up on the mandible (not on the soft tissues). This lifts the tongue away from the posterior pharynx and improves airway patency.

 

There is no absolute contraindication to it but Suspected cervical injury is a relative contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Jaw thrust: Lift the mandible upward with your fingers, at least until the lower incisors are higher than the upper incisors. This maneuver lifts the tongue along with the mandible, thus relieving upper airway obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Manual inline stabilization: is a neck immobilisation technique in a natural position achieved by using the fingers and palms of both hands to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to gently counteract the forces of airway intervention

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The head-tilt chin-lift maneuver is a key technique for opening the airway in emergency situations, especially when cervical spine injury is not suspected.

questions.text: Which protein is responsible for connecting the Z-lines to the M-lines within a myofibril? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Titin

 

Explanation:

 

Titin is the largest known protein in the human body with a molecular mass of approximately 3,000,000 Da. It plays a critical structural role in the sarcomere by connecting the Z-lines to the M-lines, thereby providing essential scaffolding for the entire sarcomeric structure. Titin also contributes significantly to muscle elasticity through its folded domains that can unfold during initial stretching (providing low resistance) and then offer increasing resistance with further stretch to protect sarcomere integrity.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Kinin: Kinins are inflammatory mediators and not structural proteins of muscle fibers. They have no role in connecting sarcomeric components.
  • Option b. Desmin: While desmin is an important structural protein, it functions by adding structure to the Z-lines through binding them to the plasma membrane. It does not connect Z-lines to M-lines.
  • Option d. Actin: Actin forms the thin filaments of the sarcomere and does not serve as a connecting protein between Z-lines and M-lines. It interacts with myosin during muscle contraction but does not have a structural scaffolding role between these components.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Titin functions as a molecular spring providing both elasticity and structural integrity to the sarcomere by forming a continuous filament from Z-line to M-line, making it essential for proper muscle function and sarcomere stability.

questions.text: A capnograph obtained from an intubated patient undergoing controlled ventilation is given below. Which of the following is a likely cause of the finding seen? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spontaneous respiratory effort

 

  • The capnograph shows a characteristic pattern known as the curare notch or curare cleft.
  • This pattern indicates spontaneous inspiratory effort by the patient during controlled mechanical ventilation.
  • This occurs when the patient attempts to breathe against the ventilator cycle, causing a dip in the capnograph waveform.
  • The appropriate next step would be to paralyze the patient again by administering an additional dose of muscle relaxant to ensure proper synchronization with the ventilator.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophageal intubation: In cases of esophageal intubation, the capnograph typically shows a very low or absent end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2) reading because the endotracheal tube is not in the trachea, leading to little to no CO2 being detected. The waveform would be almost flat.

 

 

Option B. Inspiration with cardiac oscillations: Cardiac oscillations can appear on the capnograph as small oscillations or ripples on the expiratory plateau due to the beating of the heart causing minor fluctuations in airway pressure. This is not characterized by a distinct cleft or notch.

 

 

Option C. Bronchospasm: Bronchospasm causes a "shark fin" appearance on the capnograph due to obstructed airflow and prolonged expiration. The waveform would show a slanted, rather than a squared-off, expiratory plateau.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A curare notch or cleft on a capnograph indicates spontaneous respiratory effort in a patient who is supposed to be fully ventilated under muscle relaxants, requiring re-administration of the muscle relaxant to ensure proper mechanical ventilation.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1311

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery is maintained on anesthesia with halothane. During the procedure, the patient suddenly developed hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suxamethonium

 

The scenario described involves a patient undergoing surgery who suddenly develops hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. This is indicative of a condition called Malignant Hyperthermia (MH), which is a rare but potentially life-threatening reaction to certain medications used during anesthesia.

 

In this case, the most likely drug implicated in causing MH is:

 

Suxamethonium (also known as succinylcholine)

 

  • Suxamethonium is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent commonly used for muscle relaxation during surgery.
  • However, it is known to be associated with triggering malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals.
  • MH is a severe reaction that can cause a rapid increase in body temperature, muscle rigidity, and other complications.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Doxacurium: Doxacurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used to induce muscle relaxation during surgery. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option C. Atracurium: Atracurium is another non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used in anesthesia. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Rocuronium: Rocuronium is also a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. Like atracurium and doxacurium, it is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The drug most likely implicated in causing malignant hyperthermia in the given scenario is suxamethonium (succinylcholine) because it is known to trigger this condition in susceptible individuals.

 

Treatment - Dantrolene sodium and supportive management

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can be treated with pirenzepine? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Peptic ulcer disease

 

The M1 muscarinic receptors in the stomach increase the acid secretion. Pirenzepine is an M1 blocker, which can help in reducing the acid secretion and thereby was used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Asthma is typically treated with bronchodilators (e.g., beta-agonists) and anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., corticosteroids). Pirenzepine is not used in the treatment of asthma.

 

Option C. Glaucoma: Glaucoma is often treated with medications that reduce intraocular pressure, such as beta-blockers, prostaglandin analogs, or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. Pirenzepine is not indicated for the treatment of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Hypertension: Hypertension is treated with a variety of medications including diuretics, ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, and others. Pirenzepine is not used in the management of hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pirenzepine is an M1 muscarinic receptor antagonist that reduces gastric acid secretion and is used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. It is not indicated for conditions such as asthma, glaucoma, or hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones inhibits gastric motility and gastric emptying at physiological concentrations? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Cholecystokinin

 

Explanation

 

Cholecystokinin (CCK) physiologically inhibits gastric motility and gastric emptying. It decreases gastric emptying by inhibiting the pylorus and causing contraction of the pyloric sphincter. This mechanism allows food to remain in the stomach longer, providing adequate time for digestion before the chyme enters the small intestine.
