This inhibitory effect coordinates with CCK's stimulatory effects on pancreatic enzyme secretion and gallbladder contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Gastrin Gastrin has the opposite effect on gastric emptying. It helps in pyloric sphincter relaxation and positively influences gastric emptying. By relaxing the pyloric sphincter, gastrin promotes rather than inhibits the movement of stomach contents into the duodenum.
  • Option C. GLP (Glucagon-Like Peptide) is produced by L cells in the intestine but doesn't have a primary role in inhibiting gastric motility or emptying at physiological concentrations. Its functions are primarily related to other gastrointestinal and metabolic processes.
  • Option D. Motilin Motilin increases GI motility rather than inhibiting it. Prokinetic drugs that stimulate motilin receptors (Mo cells) can cause diarrhea due to this stimulatory effect. Motilin promotes rather than inhibits gastric motility and is considered a prokinetic hormone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CCK physiologically inhibits gastric emptying by causing contraction of the pyloric sphincter, which works together with its other actions like gallbladder contraction and enzyme secretion to optimize digestion timing.

choices.text: 50 breaths per minute or more

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT suggest a possible severe bacterial infection in a young infant according to the IMNCI criteria? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Axillary temperature of 37.5°C or above 

 

Explanation: 

 

The IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) protocol uses specific clinical criteria to identify young infants with potential severe bacterial infections requiring urgent treatment. An axillary temperature of 37.5°C represents a normal body temperature and falls below the fever threshold of ≥38.0°C, which would indicate infection. A temperature between 36.5°C and 37.5°C is considered normal and would not trigger the "fever" classification in the IMNCI assessment.

 

The WHO IMNCI classification system specifically designates fever as temperature ≥38°C when assessing for possible severe bacterial infection. Without other clinical signs, a temperature of 37.5°C alone would be classified as "no fever" and would not meet criteria for antibiotic therapy or referral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 50 breaths per minute or more - This is a danger sign in IMNCI assessment. The age-specific respiratory rate cutoffs (≥60/min for <2 months; ≥50/min for 2-12 months) define fast breathing, which is classified as pneumonia requiring antibiotic therapy or severe pneumonia if accompanied by chest indrawing.

 

Option B. 10 or more skin pustules - This IS considered a sign of possible severe bacterial infection. The IMNCI guidelines classify multiple skin pustules or a large skin infection as requiring systemic antibiotics due to risk of invasive bacterial disease.

 

Option D. Temperature less than 35.5°C - This IS a critical danger sign. Hypothermia in young infants strongly suggests sepsis and represents impaired thermoregulation. IMNCI classifies temperature <35.5°C as a danger sign requiring immediate referral after pre-referral antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In IMNCI assessment, normal temperature (36.5-37.5°C) does not trigger concern for severe bacterial infection, while fast breathing (age-specific rates), multiple skin infections, and hypothermia (<35.5°C) all represent important clinical signs requiring prompt antibiotic therapy and possible referral.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient visits his family practitioner for a yearly examination. On examination, his BP was 190/100 mm Hg. His pulse pressure was 90 mm Hg. What would have decreased resulting in this increase in pulse pressure?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arterial wall compliance

 

Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and it reflects the compliance (elasticity) of the arterial walls. In this scenario, the patient has a high systolic blood pressure and a normal diastolic blood pressure, resulting in an increased pulse pressure of 90 mm Hg (190 mm Hg - 100 mm Hg = 90 mm Hg).

 

Arterial wall compliance refers to the ability of the arteries to expand and contract with each heartbeat, which helps maintain a steady blood pressure. Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, which can cause an increase in systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial contractility: Incorrect. While myocardial contractility can influence blood pressure, it is not directly related to the increase in pulse pressure in this scenario.

 

Option B. Stroke volume: Incorrect. Stroke volume affects cardiac output and overall blood pressure but is not the primary factor in the increase in pulse pressure observed here.

 

Option D. Cardiac output: Incorrect. Cardiac output can affect overall blood pressure, but the specific increase in pulse pressure in this case is more closely linked to decreased arterial wall compliance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased arterial wall compliance leads to increased stiffness of the arteries, resulting in higher systolic blood pressure and an increased pulse pressure, as observed in the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT involved in renal auto-regulation?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Renal sympathetic system fires

 

Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure very widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.

The sympathetic nervous system can also influence renal blood flow, but its role is primarily to modulate GFR in response to systemic conditions rather than as part of the intrinsic autoregulatory mechanisms. Therefore, renal sympathetic system firing is not considered a key component of renal autoregulation.

 

Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:

 

  1. Myogenic response - mechanism that contributes to the maintenance of a relatively constant renal blood flow and GFR
  2. Tubuloglomerular feedback via macula densa. Renin-angiotensin system also plays a role.

 

 

 

 

Macula densa feedback mechanism for autoregulation of glomerular hydrostatic pressure and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) during decreased renal arterial pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubuloglomerular feedback: Incorrect. Tubuloglomerular feedback is a key component of renal autoregulation.

 

Option B. Myogenic reflex: Incorrect. The myogenic reflex is a crucial mechanism in renal autoregulation.The myogenic reflex helps regulate GFR by directly responding to changes in blood pressure (BP) within the afferent arteriole, which supplies blood to the glomerulus. When BP  increases, the afferent arteriole smooth muscle stretches, triggering a contraction (vasoconstriction) that reduces blood flow into the glomerulus, thus decreasing GFR.

 

Option C. Renin-angiotensin system: Incorrect. The renin-angiotensin system supports renal autoregulation, particularly in adjusting the efferent arteriolar resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal autoregulation primarily involves the myogenic response and tubuloglomerular feedback mechanisms to maintain stable GFR. The renal sympathetic system, while involved in renal blood flow regulation, is not part of intrinsic autoregulation mechanisms.
